Award.AwardTitle: ELT COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Investigating the Biotic and Paleoclimatic Consequences of Dust in the Late Paleozoic
Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborative Research:
Investigating the Biotic and Paleoclimatic Consequences of Dust in the Late Paleozoic

by

Gerilyn Soreghan, University of Oklahoma, EAR-1338331
Sarah Aciego, University of Michigan, EAR-1337440
Linda Hinnov, Johns Hopkins University, EAR-1337454
Nicholas Heavens, Hampton University, EAR-1337463

Overview
Geologic data indicate that the tropical atmosphere during the Permo-Pennsylvanian (300 Million years ago) was dust-rich. In addition, algae predominated in late Paleozoic marine ecosystems. These observations, combined with predictions from climate modeling, prompt two over-arching hypotheses driving the proposed research: 1) the unusual tropical dustiness reflects dust production by tropical upland glaciers, and 2) atmospheric dustiness fertilized marine ecosystems. Dust forces the climate system by affecting radiative forcing and atmospheric moisture, and by influencing the biosphere, but these effects are poorly known. In this research, PIs will collect data to constrain spatial (low-mid latitude) and temporal (glacial-interglacial and longer) variations in atmospheric 'dustiness,' sources of the dust, and influences between dust and ecosystem composition in order to address their over-arching hypotheses, and clarify the relationships among atmospheric dustiness, climate, and the biosphere.

Intellectual Merit
This research will reveal process links among dust, climate, and the biosphere within an icehouse, at glacial-interglacial scales. Owing to the known importance but great uncertainty of both the direct and indirect effects of dust on climate, results will expand understanding of Earth-system behavior. Tropical glaciation at low elevations implies much more widespread glaciation than currently accepted, and --if verified-- would force the community to test this hypothesis with new modeling approaches. The models to be used are identical to those used for present and future climate, and thus improvements made through the proposed work will inform modeling of Earth's climate in general. If the hypothesis that atmospheric dustiness forced marine biotic systems toward nutrient-rich conditions is confirmed, it implies a remarkably dusty Earth, and clarifies Earth-system behavior to dust-sourced fertilization. These results are relevant to growing discussions regarding geo-engineering schemes to control future climate change.

Broader Impacts
Cross-disciplinary training will occur via exchanges between geological and geochemical labs, geologists and modelers, and in joint field excursions and progress meetings. PhD students will mentor middle-school teachers through a formal summer program. Undergraduates will conduct senior theses and present at Undergraduate Research Day and national meetings. Both will interact with middle- and high-school students through a formal course on STEM education. The lead investigators will use components of the research to teach at university levels, as well as in museum, and community outreach. Ties will be established and strengthened among all participant institutions, which includes an Historically Black University, as well as international partners. This research will help ignite the research careers of three young investigators (2 with no prior NSF support). Data will be archived and shared via publications, and web-accessible tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dust storms are a common hazard in drier regions of the Earth. Dust transported over the ocean can shade its surface, cooling global climate and reducing the potential for hurricanes and tropical storms. Dust can carry nutrients critical for plants and plant-like organisms in the sea and on land, enabling life to flourish in water or soils that ordinarily would be poor of nutrients. These plants will consume more carbon dioxide than they would without dust, resulting in cooler global climate in another way. Sometimes, dust flying through the atmosphere can make it easier for ice to condense in clouds, modifying the warming or cooling effects clouds can have on climate. During the last two million years, records from rocks on land, glaciers, and the deep ocean suggest the Earth has been unusually dusty. Rock-based records from a time interval known as the Late Paleozoic Ice Age, 330-270 million years ago, have suggested that this period may have been more dusty than the last two million years. Particularly unusual is how much dust seems to have been deposited in areas located very near to the Equator 300 million years ago, such as present day Colorado, Oklahoma, and France. Dust storms very rarely have occurred in the tropics during the last two million years.

One aim of this project was to improve our knowledge of how dusty the Earth was during the Late Paleozoic Ice Age by expanding the number of rock-based records of dust (particularly in areas outside the tropics 300 million years ago) and doing physical modeling of global dust transport to match the dust deposition in those records to determine how dusty it was. Initial modeling based on the tropical dust records suggested that the Earth was six times dustier than it was before industrial agriculture or about three times dustier than today. New rock-based records from Iran, Bolivia, and Svalbard were identified and measured. It also was found that a significant portion of the ash in coal from the Late Paleozoic Ice Age and millions of years thereafter comes from atmospheric dust. Coal ash is a significant source of health-hazardous pollution and high ash coal does not burn very well. So understanding the relationship between dust and coal ash could be used to provide more records of past dust deposition and help miners find cleaner coal.

Another aim of this project was to determine if dust during the Late Paleozoic Ice Age was made by glaciers grinding rocks, sand grains colliding with one another, or some other way. Past work suggested that dust found in rocks from the tropics had come from older rocks in the tropics. In this project, evidence was found for mountain glaciers in the tropics at much lower altitudes than during the last two million years. The grinding of a huge mountain range near the Equator by these glaciers may explain the large amounts of tropical dust. But it is difficult to understand why the tropics were cold enough for glaciers to be so widespread. This project found that explosive volcanic eruptions were 3-8 times (or more) more frequent than today, which would have generated more sulfate aerosol to block sunlight. More volcanic eruptions also might have produced more sulfuric acid, which could have made dust more nutritious and helped plants lower carbon dioxide levels. 

This project also found independent evidence that dust was more nutritious for plant-like organisms in the sea during the Late Paleozoic Ice Age than during the last two million years. If true, physical and biogeochemical modeling suggests that plant growth in the sea (and the resulting carbon dioxide removal) could have been up to 240% greater than today because of more widespread and nutritious dust.

The broader impacts of this project at Hampton University were the training of two graduate students in atmospheric and planetary sciences in physical modeling of Earth's ancient climate and the provision of summer research opportunities in the possible impacts of ancient climates on ancient organisms to two visiting undergraduate students in meteorology.
